Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Combustion-Powered, Flapping-Wing Micro Air Vehicle

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will demonstrate an insect-sized flying robot powered by combustion, with a hard exoskeleton and integrated soft actuators. The premise is that structure, propulsion, snd control inspired by the insect musculoskeletal system will produce more efficient and robust microrobots. The analogy becomes even more clear with the realization that, like most animals, insects chemically burn glucose (a hydrocarbon) for muscle actuation. Conservative estimates suggest that the use of combustion to power flying microrobots will allow untethered and autonomous operation for greater than 30 minutes in idealized conditions, enabling vastly more effective application to search and rescue, inspection of infrastructure, and distributed sensor networks. In addition, this project will have broad impacts in education, harnessing children's natural interest in insect biology towards a STEM outcome of understanding robotics.

The combustion of hydrocarbons can have up to fifty times the volumetric energy density of lithium polymer batteries and is a potential power source for untethered robots, even at the scale of insects. This research is to show how combustion-powered actuation of a soft, artificial muscle can generate sufficiently high frequencies and forces to power flapping-wing micro-aerial vehicles. Typical combustion-powered machines require heavy and complex transmission systems to effectively use chemical energy. Instead, this research will develop soft, elastomeric bladders that expand during combustion, and serve as both engine and transmission -- drastically reducing complexity and weight. Flying robots are the target application for this project due to the extreme energetic demands of flight at small scales but the results will be broadly applicable to other power-demanding autonomous systems. Furthermore, the small scale of the envisioned robot will produce innovations in multi-scale multi-material manufacturing. The work will take place in three tasks: (i) fabrication and testing of a microscale soft engine; (ii) integration of the combustion chamber with a flapping-wing robot platform; (iii) development of additional technologies required for autonomous flight and performing tethered controlled flight experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we developed a soft, compressed air powered actuator, integrated said actuator into a micro aerial vehicle, and demonstrated cyclic flapping kinematics at a variety of frequencies. The use of compressed air served as a proxy to true, combustion-based actuation, which we also demonstrated separately using gaseous butane and oxygen. This work taken with the DEA robot produced by the Harvard team, shows that soft artificial muscles can be embedded in microrobots to generate dynamic movements at high frequencies (> 125 Hz) and large power densities (320 W kg-1).

The soft compressed air engine was fabricated using a combination of stereolithography (SLA) 3D printing and replica molding. SLA, with its rapid production times and high design precision at sub millimeter scales, enabled us to create a lightweight (155 mg) actuation chamber capable of fitting within existing RoboBee airframes. Future combustion based designs, requiring additional apertures, valves, and ventilation holes, each with finely tuned geometries would also benefit from the resolution and capabilities of SLA printing. The actuation chamber was printed from a urethane methacrylate (UMA90) resin using a Carbon M1 SLA printer and measured approximately 12 mm x 6 mm x 5 mm. The shape of the chamber was experimentally optimized to meet the design constraints of the RoboBee platform; the internal volume was decreased to enable actuation with small volumes of injected air (~ 0.1 mL), the exterior actuation membrane areas (72 mm2) were maximized to increase the actuation amplitude, and the overall form factor was trimmed of all excess material to decrease weight.

The actuating membrane was created using Dragonskin 10 silicone rubber (Smooth-On). We selected Dragonskin 10 due to its favorable material properties, including low stiffness (E100% ~ 150 kPa), large maximal strain (emax = 1000%), and durability. During initial testing, other proposed membrane materials exhibited plastic deformation at relevant strains and high degrees of viscoelasticity that created asymmetric inflation and deflation cycles. We cast 500µm thickness Dragonskin 10 membranes and affixed these to the printed actuation chamber using Loctite SF 770 primer and Loctite 416 superglue.

These soft engines were connected to a compressed air source by way of a short length of tubing and a high frequency solenoid valve. The opening and closing of this solenoid valve was regulated by an Arduino microcontroller, allowing us to set the valve/actuator frequency. The solenoid allowed small volumes of air to enter into and cyclically inflate the actuation chamber. Deflation was passively achieved via three 350 µm diameter ventilation holes printed into the chamber. The unloaded actuator was able to inflate to an amplitude of ~ 900 µm on either side while being cyclically actuated at a rate of 100 Hz. Testing with a load cell confirmed that the actuator applied an average force of greater than 225 mN during actuation. The results of these unloaded tests meet or exceed the performance metrics demonstrated by previous, flight-worthy RoboBee designs2. As an example, RoboBees produced by our Harvard collaborators have achieved lift at 70 Hz using piezo actuators that apply a force of 200 mN at an amplitude of 650-850 µm peak-to-peak. These soft actuators also produce ~ 50 mW of power at 100 Hz and, excluding the compressed air tether, have a maximum power density of ~ 320 W kg-1.

A new RoboBee airframe was collaboratively designed to accommodate the soft engine before being assembled by the Harvard team. The two actuating membranes are symmetrically connected to identical transmissions, wing hinges, and wings. Much like the DEA design produced by the Harvard team, this configuration allows the same actuator to simultaneously actuate both wings. The inflation and deflation of the soft actuator are converted into the wing’s rotational stroke motion via the robot’s transmission. Wing actuation is asymmetric in this design, as membrane inflation occurs slightly faster than deflation.

Actuation tests were conducted using the same tethered compressed air testing setup and a high speed camera. With the robot fixed in place, we demonstrated full-stroke flapping kinematics at a maximum actuation frequency of 50 Hz (Fig. 3) using large wings (Length = 2.4 cm) and 125 Hz using medium sized wings (Length = 1.3 cm). For the large-winged design, the actuation frequency was limited by high inertial forces on the wings, which created a frequency offset that destructively interfered with cyclic flapping above 50Hz. The wing stroke was truncated when the medium-winged design was driven at frequencies above 125 Hz, though flapping motions upwards of 160 Hz were also recorded.
